question: Question_01_(j)
statement:
Let \emph{f} and \emph{g} be functions such that

\[\displaystyle f'(x)\]

and

\[\displaystyle g'(x)\]

are both continuous and increasing for all real numbers \emph{x}. Which
of the following is ALWAYS true?

\emph{f} + \emph{g} is concave up everywhere

\emph{f} - \emph{g} is concave up everywhere

\emph{f} Â· \emph{g} is concave up everywhere

I only

II only

I and II only

I and III only

I, II, and III
sols:
We can consider statements I, II, III individually to which of them are
true.

\subsection{Statement I: \emph{f} + \emph{g} is Concave Up
Everywhere}\label{statement-i-f-g-is-concave-up-everywhere}

Let

\[\displaystyle H = f + g\]

Statement I is true if the second derivative of \emph{H} is positive for
all real numbers \emph{x}. The second derivative of \emph{H} is

\[\displaystyle H'' = f'' + g''.\]

However,

\[\displaystyle f'' (x)\]

and

\[\displaystyle g'' (x)\]

must be positive for all real numbers (because f' and g' are continuous
and increasing for all \emph{x}), so

\[\displaystyle H'' (x)\]

must be positive for all \emph{x}. Statement I is true.

\subsection{Statement II: \emph{f} - \emph{g} is Concave Up
Everywhere}\label{statement-ii-f---g-is-concave-up-everywhere}

If we let

\[\displaystyle H = f - g\]

then

\[\displaystyle H'' = f'' - g''.\]

However,

\[\displaystyle f'' (x)\]

could be less than

\[\displaystyle g'' (x)\]

for all real numbers, so

\[\displaystyle H'' (x)\]

may not be positive for all \emph{x}. Statement II is false.

\subsection{Statement III: \emph{f} Â· \emph{g} is Concave Up
Everywhere}\label{statement-iii-f-uxe2-g-is-concave-up-everywhere}

If we let

\[\displaystyle H = f \cdot g\]

then

\[\displaystyle H'' = f''g + 2f'g' + fg''.\]

We know that

\[\displaystyle f'' (x), g'' (x)\]

are both positive for all real numbers, but we don't necessarily have
that

\[\displaystyle f'(x), g'(x), f(x), g(x)\]

are necessarily positive. So it is possible that $f''g+fg''$ is negative
and outweighs the positive term $2f'g'$. For example, choose

\[\displaystyle f(x) = x^2-1,\ g(x) = x^2\]

Then

\[\displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x) = 2x\]

is increasing but

\[\displaystyle f''g+2f'g'+2fg'' = (2)(x^2)+2(2x)(2x)+(x^2-1)(2) = 12x^2-2\]

which is negative for small values of \emph{x} (e.g. when \emph{x = 0}).

Statement III is false.

\subsection{The Answer}\label{the-answer}

The answer is (A) I only.
hints:
What do you know about $f''(x)$ and $g''(x)$ from the statement of the
problem?

To test (I), define a function $H = f + g$. What is the value of the
second derivative of $H$?

You can use a similar method to test II and III.
